text: thinner John Kerry thanks so much for
joining us thank you as you know
Democrats got pasted in the governor's
races in Virginia and New Jersey this
week you know how this place works and
how politicians get spooked by election
results how is that going to affect the
way some of your Democratic colleagues
especially the moderates and
conservatives behave on issues like
health care climate change Afghanistan I
don't think it's going to change their
approach you know health care has a life
of its own people are looking for the
best way to lower the costs and provide
people with quality care that doesn't
change because of the election and I
think people were have been intent
having worked on this on the Finance
Committee I'm confident of it have been
intent on succeeding so it's the outcome
we're looking for and not the politics
aren't some of these blue dogs though
going to say wait a minute spending big
government Washington is not popular
well this is a bill the this bill we
have been absolutely fixated on making a
deficit-neutral and it's at CBO right
now the reason it's being delayed is
we're waiting for the numbers we're
legislating in a in a remarkably
responsible way not always the history
here in the Washington so I think people
are going to be guided by the guarantee
that they're really going to do what the
bill sets out to do lower the cost
provide quality care improve the system
I think those will be the tests the
reality of this election season and
probably next year is ten percent
unemployment what should the Congress do
about that beyond what you guys have
already done well our ability to do a
great deal about it beyond what we've
already done is limited I mean we can't
continue to pile a deficit you know into
infinity and we have a serious fiscal
challenge facing us now I think no new
jobs tax credit no I think I think what
you'll see is first of all the the
energy
the bill that we've put together to deal
with energy and climate is in fact a
jobs bill a very significant jobs bill
it's going to have a profound impact on
America's economy it's going to excite
major new investment it's going to
result in jobs being created in America
and kept in America and I'm very excited
about it for that reason I think it is a
stimulus package in effect so that's
going to have a huge impact next year
and all the indicators are coming back
from almost every analysis that this
provides investment money in two states
and creates jobs in states all across
our country so you know people really
need to step back and get away from the
quick hit political slogans that have
been used to define the this legislation
and look at its true impact it's one of
the reasons the Chamber of Commerce
changed its view the other day and said
indeed we've got to do this this
Congress and and what they want to make
sure is that we do it in a reasonable
and smart way well so does that mean
that you think this idea of some sort of
a new job creation tax credit that
speaker Pelosi's talked about that
President Obama talked about in the
campaign is a non-starter because I
can't afford no I don't think that's a
non-starter I think you could have some
targeted selected efforts you asked me
about a big stimulus package I say no I
don't think you're going to see that
except to the degree that it is
contained in legislation that we need to
do for a lot of other reasons too so I
think that you know I'm also i think
that we're already coming out of this
it's a slower growth and some people
would like employment unfortunately
always lags behind that kind of recovery
but we are a lot better off I mean
people really don't know how close we
were to the precipice back in January in
February when president became president
he had to make some extraordinary tough
decisions up front early he did that and
really rescued a struggling system very
early next year if not at the end of
this year depending on the health care
debate we're going to be getting into
financial regulatory reform that will
have an impact go in fixing the system
and then we get the energy climate piece
done and that creates jobs I think
by the middle of next summer somewhere
you could begin to see some some real
progress that people can you know grab
ahold of so you think the economy is in
better shape than many people now
appreciate in terms of its the arc of
recovery and that members of Congress
your fellow Democrats ought to be
content to run and make that argument I
think that John that clearly were in
better shape than we were in january of
februari when we were at the precipice
of major failures beyond what we
experienced we have yet distance to go I
don't think any of us are sitting here
sanguine that there aren't things we
can't do to continue to kick the economy
into gear and that we shouldn't do we
should health care is one of them health
care if we reduce the burden on business
and we spread the costs more
intelligently throughout our economy
we're going to have a positive impact on
that economy secondly if we get the
energy independence jobs bill done that
will excite new investment new jobs and
States and we were already seeing it the
fastest growing sectors of most of our
states in the country today is not the
traditional economy it's the alternative
energy renewable energy efficiency
energy economy and that's where the
change is coming if we can kick that
into higher gear we can you know we're
looking at a six trillion dollar market
globally and a six billion dollar six
billion user market compare that to the
1990s when we created unbelievable
wealth in America with a 1 trillion
dollar market and 1 billion users so
we're looking at an enormous opportunity
and we need to grab it you wrote an
op-ed column with Lindsey Graham a
couple of weeks ago that said yes we can
pass a bill on climate change I
interviewed your Democratic colleague
Ben Nelson the other day and he said no
we can't and the reason is that it's
going to raise costs for everybody flips
on a light switch I thought Ben is
respectfully I like Ben and I've chatted
with him briefly about it but he's
actually wrong about that in terms of
the net impact on States and on
individuals household income actually
goes up under that legislation because
while the unit price
of gas or the unit price of electricity
might go up individually the overall
costs of an individual at home in their
total consumption will go down because
of energy efficiencies more efficient
automobiles and so forth so it's too
quick a hit just to say costs are going
to go up in fact the studies by
reputable companies like the McKinsey
company or other entities in the country
the University of California Berkeley
various entities of done analyses show
job growth and show a very very minimal
cost increase to families across America
I mean very minimal even if you're right
in the political culture that we live in
isn't the quick hit that Senator Nelson
mentioned the kind of thing that's fatal
to a big piece of legislation I don't
think it will be on this because the
imperatives I mean that's why a lindsey
graham from south carolina is saying we
have to do this that's why joe lieberman
an independent Democrat who you know has
often been right at the center of some
of these debates is very powerfully
committed to saying we need to do this
that's why businesses across country
we're dropping out of the chamber of
commerce why isn't your friend by the
john mccain with you in this effort by
the way he was supporting cap and trade
in the campaign is he not a maverick
anymore oh i think john is being very
thoughtful about it and i'm confident
that he is going to look at this very
closely what we're doing we anticipate
you know sharing with him everything we
are doing in hopes of bring him aboard
and I I feel confident that John McCain
remains deeply committed on this issue
it's been a signature issue for him I
think he sees other people so doing
their pieces right now that's
appropriate but my hope is that at the
right time John McCain will step in and
show the leadership that John McCain has
the ability to and has many times
demonstrated not only on this issue but
on others you've both run for president
your good friends you've even
entertained the idea of running with him
what's your relationship like with him
no it's good John and I
like any two people are on the opposite
sides of the fence and a couple of
issues namely my run for president and
his run for president are inevitably
going to you know find little friction
in that process and I think it's fair to
say we did but it's also fair to say
that we both have much bigger interests
we both traveled beyond that moment and
we both want to be constructive in the
United States Senate and have mutual
respect for each of our journeys so I
very much we've SAT we've talked we're
going to work on things we're going to
find things to do together and I
obviously hope very much that this will
be one of them you mentioned in your
op-ed with Lindsey Graham that we should
not let countries that don't adhere to
environmental standards take jobs from
us and you raise the idea of a tax on
imports from countries that don't adhere
to those standards are you suggesting a
tax on imports from China I'm suggesting
that it is appropriate for any country
that has signed up to an international
global agreement that we are going to
behave in a certain way that if one or
two countries decide to stay outside of
that mechanism of that agreement and
they think they're going to take
advantage of our marketplace at the
expense of our jobs because we signed up
to international agreement they ought to
be wrong they are wrong and I think it
is entirely within the legal
international legal standards for
countries to set up an enforcement
mechanism whereby if countries decide to
try to clean our clock in the
marketplace by taking advantage of the
fact that we're going to do what's
responsible and they're not it's
entirely appropriate for us to make it
harder for them to sell their products
in our market now that sounds like that
is a that is an accepted principle of
any kind of global environmental
agreement and I think other countries
will welcome and join into that kind of
a protocol now that sounds like a
warning to China and India but if China
and India stay out of that protocol
doesn't that mean the Copenhagen process
isn't going anywhere anyway what did
what it means is that it's gonna be much
more difficult to get a climate
agreement here in the United States and
it means that any major country that
decides did not come to some kind of an
agreement in Copenhagen will bear
responsibility conceivably for its
failure but it doesn't mean that we're
not going to proceed had a head in some
ways because we need to I mean look
right now John in the United States of
America over half of our economy is
already voluntarily under a mandatory
reduction scheme you have 11 to i think
or 13 states in the Northeast of New
England who've come together in what's
called Reggie the regional New England
program to reduce emissions you have a
Midwest program that encompasses about
five to seven states you have a Western
program with Oregon Washington
California Canada where they've agreed
to reduce emissions you add those up
it's over fifty percent of the american
economy is moving way ahead of
washington DC washington politicians are
behind the private sector behind
businesses and behind over 1,000 mayor's
in america who have signed on to the
mayor's conference emissions reduction
proposal so Washington is truly not even
following on this yet and we have a long
way to go to catch up well speaking of
that word on the street is that because
Washington's behind and because we'll
take a lot of flack at Copenhagen the
President Obama will not go is that the
right well i hope the words not accurate
no i don't think it's the right course
for the president think he should go i
think the president should go and i
think the president should go to China
with a proposal to China that's specific
I believe he can get an agreement with
China I believe that will leverage
Copenhagen to a political agreement
where the nations come together and I
think the president can be critical to
helping to deliver that as can we in the
Senate and and Senator Graham and
Senator Lieberman and I are intent on
trying to get the framework of a
proposal together so that we know what
the Senate outlines of a debate will be
and we can go to Copenhagen and help
that process let's talk about health
care for a second I talked to one of
your colleagues the other day who's
planning to vote for whatever health
care bill comes out of the process but
who said this is a tough vote and we're
going to take some political flack for
it because we're going to raise people's
insurance premiums what about that set a
problem for your members are you guys go
there's a problem pay a price next year
well it is a problem right now but it's
a problem that I can be addressed and I
think other colleagues believe that too
we are working on the affordability
issues with respect to this bill it's
currently being evaluated by the
Congressional Budget Office we need to
get those numbers back so then we can
look at it and see if we need to adjust
and be a little more flexible but how
we're approaching it but I think it's a
problem for anybody it's problem for me
I don't want to turn around and say to
people we're going to make health care
more affordable in America and we're
going to improve the system in all of a
sudden they see prices going up beyond
what they're going to go up anyway so
the answer your subsidies very important
to understand health care premiums are
going to go up no matter what we did
they're going to go up next year they've
been going up at 28 and 40 and 50 and
100 percent for some people what we're
trying to do is slow down that increase
but obviously whenever you take a tough
vote that's a responsible boat around
here and there's a lag between the
beneficial effect being felt and the
time the boat is taken people are a
little at risk how do you moderate
insurance premiums you is it with
subsidies or is it with regulation how
do you prevent this combination it's
absolutely a combination we we have a
subsidy structure that comes in to help
reduce the cost for individuals who
can't afford it on a certain scale and
that scale is yet to be finalized and we
have insurance regulatory reforms that
hopefully tamping down the proclivity of
those companies to keep raising rates at
the speed that they have and it's the
combination of those that need to begin
to take hold and produce the beneficial
effects do you think it's important
because of the effects on bending the
cost curve over time to preserve the tax
on high-value insurance plans as opposed
to the approach the house has taken a
taxing high dollar incomes over a
million dollars you know there are a
number of different ways to pay for the
bill and different people will have
different thoughts about how to do it my
own predisposition is to keep the
component of the high cost plans at a
high enough threshold that you're not
pushing it down onto people and and you
know having giving them a sense that
they're being unfairly hurt here but at
the higher level that will create
pressure within the industry in a
competitive world to hold those premiums
down because they want to be competitive
and so I think it's one of the things
that can actually bend the cost curve
and that's why I would argue we ought to
try to keep it the public option is one
of the flash points in the debate as you
know the administration is indicated
that they're willing to accept the
trigger idea that Olympia Snowe your
colleague has embraced and there's a lot
of concern out there about big
government should liberals in your party
be prepared to accept that trigger in
lieu of pressing for that vigorous
robust public option from day one in
order to get this thing through
especially since the White House says
they want Republican support well let's
begin at the beginning here first the
so-called public option that is on the
table is not what a lot of Americans
think it is when they hear the word
public option it's not like Medicare
it's not a great big public plan like
that you know that you can come in and
the government is going to offer you
this insurance it's not free it only
applies to a very small percentage of
Americans who would be eligible for that
and that's about fifteen percent total
and only about five percent whatever of
those are going to take it so you're
talking about a very small component of
people being affected by a plan that is
called public plan but number one
requires all of the premiums to be paid
by the individual and has no public
dollars in it except in the first year
of start up it has to be self-sustaining
and it has to operate by the same rule
as the private plans so we shouldn't get
hung up over this quote debate about the
public option it's a it's a far cry less
than what many of us believe ought to be
debated as a matter of a public option
second we shouldn't shy away from a
debate about a public plan let's have
the debate we should even have a debate
about a single-payer plan if people want
to have it and and take the votes and
let people's votes stand for the record
of what's achievable here and what is
not achievable here and that's the way
you arrive at a consensus about a
fallback position in your view is the
trigger trigger is a proposition is that
the maximum achievable in this Congress
the trigger is a fallback position and
I'm not prepared to say until we have
the debate and see where the votes are
what's achievable yet I think you've got
a you know let's let's engage in that
without fear on that it's a great debate
and we'll decide what the Senate is
willing to to do if you can't get it
done John I happen to be prepared I mean
I Olympia and I have worked on this
actually together I I think you need
some kind of a fallback option at the
back end of this so that we don't lose
this opportunity to cement in place a a
plan B in the event of failure that's
what we talked about doing in 1993-94
when I worked back then with Bill
Bradley and Pat Moynihan God packwood
Bob Dole a whole group of people on an
alternative that would have been a
backup to the clinton plan and had they
been willing to accept that back then we
would have had ninety seven percent of
all Americans covered back in 2003
that's why those kinds of fallback
things I think are very worthwhile and I
think the Senate needs to just go
seriatim step one step two step three
and and we'll see where we are and the
timing of that process leader Reid's
seemed to suggest the other day it might
kick over into next year in your view is
that possible or is it important as the
White House is said to act this year
well I think it's important to act this
year and I'd like to see us at this year
but everything has obviously been pushed
back a little bit here even the energy
jobs bill has been pushed back so do you
think it will bleed into next year I
can't tell you that no I hope I mean I
would hope not but I can't sit here in a
vacuum today and tell you that because
we don't have it back from the from the
Congressional Budget Office and we
haven't started the debate and we've got
to see you know it sort of has a life of
its own you kind of have to feel where
where the tolerance levels are I think
it'd be wonderful if we could finish it
before Christmas and I think we ought to
try one question about financial
regulation before I go to Afghanistan
your Massachusetts colleague Barney
Frank has got a financial regulation
proposal that would preserve some of the
existing regulatory structure not not
have a radical consolidation as your
friend chris dodd of connecticut is
exploring in the Senate who's writing
that debate well I haven't totally
engaged completely in the two bills
because I've been so busy on these other
issues I think we need a pretty broad
transformation here and you know Chris
represents banking industry and he
represents I think a combination of both
banks and insurance that if he's calling
for a broader you know reform I'd want
to look at that very very carefully now
Barney is as smart as they come he's as
capable as they come I haven't a chance
to talk to him about the reasons he's
landed where he has and I clearly will
so you know these are very very capable
both of them very capable ledges it
sounds like your instinct is that
something perhaps more far-reaching than
the administration proposed that that's
less power in the Fed which is chris
dodd's point I really want to study it I
don't want to shoot from the hip on that
one the consequences are too important
to all of us and I want to look at it
very carefully Afghanistan you've
obviously played a big role in that
issue lately we all remember you got in
a little bit of hot water and your kin
paying for supplemental troop funding
was for it before I was against it now
some of your colleagues are likely to
face a vote on a supplemental funding
bill for the war in Afghanistan what's
going to happen there is that a real
bound on what the administration can do
or your members at the end of the day
I'm going to give the White House
whatever they want well first of all
just as a matter of the record I got in
trouble not because of the substance of
it because of the way I frame fair
enough yeah and and it was an inadequate
awkward phrasing and I paid a price for
that but the gist of what I did was
correct which was make a judgment that
if certain requisites weren't met in a
bill as you legislate you have the right
to say I'm not going to support this and
that I framed it that way who knows that
I think our colleagues are looking at
this very very carefully for all the
obvious reasons they don't want to dig a
hole for our country they don't want
young Americans called on to go into
combat for a strategy that can't succeed
because the underlying assumptions are
wrong and those are the appropriate
tests to be applying to this for the
commander-in-chief the president and for
us we have to fund it and we share a
responsibility in the conduct of Foreign
Affairs and war so he'll get what he
asked for well I think people will look
at it very carefully I think it'd be
very hard to imagine that if the
president after all of this review and
the generals after their review and
request that the Congress is going to
somehow come out differently it doesn't
mean there won't be dissenters and it
doesn't mean there won't be a debate but
in the end i believe the Congress will
providing the strategy makes sense and
and people can see a path to success and
I suspect he'll choose one where you can
I think Congress will support that the
you were involved in brokering the
runoff or getting Hamid Karzai to agree
to run off now that has gone away how
does that in your
you change your conception of
Afghanistan as a partner for the United
States the timing and substance of the
president's trip decision well it
doesn't change mine at all because
really this was anticipate abul and I
thought would probably be the way it
would turn out we had a number of very
bad options staring us in the face I
think the option of actually having the
election though it was up to Afghans as
to whether we did or not we were
entirely prepared to do it but had they
done it I could easily have foreseen the
very same arguments being made about
that election as were made about the
first election and that would have been
devastating to any potential for
credibility of the government so in fact
dr. Abdullah's withdrawal inadequate as
it is to the complete legitimization of
President Karzai puts him in a position
to legitimize himself over the course of
these next days a place we might not
have been without dr abdullah getting
out so it's really up to dr. it's really
up to President Karzai and it's up to us
together and when I say us I don't just
mean the United States I mean the IAF
forces the NATO countries to come
together around a strategy for success
not just in Afghanistan but regionally
and then pursue it with vigor forty
thousand more troops sound about right
to you as I said at the Council on
Foreign Relations I thought that without
an adequate without an adequate formula
for how we're going to get the
governance and the development
components the civilian sector of these
things at the same rate as the military
and we don't have that yet I think
40,000 pushes too far too fast and
that's those the words I used at the
Council on Foreign Relations 10,000 of
those also represent making up for the
Canadian and Dutch leaving some at the
end of next year and some of the year
beyond I think we ought to push back
against that if this is indeed
NATO priority if this is a global threat
then I think we ought to push back
against countries so dumping on the
United States the additional need to
provide for those troops your sense that
I think its present agree with you I
can't tell you that but I do think that
some troops are appropriate providing
the mission is clearly defined and the
path to success is buttressed by
adequate governance and adequate
development when I interviewed President
Obama a couple of weeks ago and asked
him about the warnings he was getting
from some colleagues about a quagmire
like Vietnam he said Afghanistan is not
Vietnam you never walk into the same
river twice do you see echoes of Vietnam
in the Afghanistan well you know
something John I work very hard not to
be imprisoned by the Vietnam experience
informed by it but not imprisoned by it
and and so not everything is Vietnam
when you see things you know you have to
really push back against some of the
analogies are there some echoes yes of
course the rest of that goes when you
have young Americans marching around in
another country with guns and full
battle gear in a place they don't speak
the language and a cup a place they
don't share the culture they don't share
the religion and they look differently
you bet there are echoes and when you
see people staring in the way that they
stare at a foreign force walking around
telling them where they can go and can't
go what they can do and so forth it has
an impact but that doesn't make
Afghanistan Vietnam at all we went there
the underlying assumptions of Vietnam
and my judgment were absolutely
incorrect the underlying assumption that
brought us to Afghanistan was clearly
correct we went there to kick al-qaeda
out hopefully to have captured and
killed Osama bin Laden his cohorts a
huge failing incidentally in strategy
but but without going back to that we
went there with a legitimate concern al
Qaeda kicking out Taliban who were
harboring them they're not there now
that mean talibans there but al Qaeda is
not and so we have to sort of ask
ourselves
are we staying in the correct way we
know we went there in the correct way
are we staying there and I think that's
a much tougher judgment given the real
threat of Pakistan the threat of the
regional instability and the fact that
if Afghanistan weren't next door to
Pakistan we almost certainly wouldn't be
there two things very quickly before I
let you go the you're in the middle of a
lot of big stuff right now but you're
not president what you want it to be how
tough is it for you to reflect as I
imagine you do from time to time a few
thousand votes in Ohio would go on the
other way I'd be sitting there making
these calls you know I am long past that
kind I mean just long past that kind of
reflection and it would be a stupid
waste of time for me to sit around and
engage in that there's too much to do
number one and it's a silly indulgence I
worked hard for President Obama to be
President I'm glad he's president I
think he's put the country on the right
track there are tough decisions yet to
be made I don't agree with absolutely
everything but but but I really believe
he has changed the direction for the
better and is making a lot of tough
decisions correctly so I'm you know very
liberated and content to be representing
the people of Massachusetts in what Ted
Kennedy always said was the greatest
privilege of his life its greatest
privilege of my life and I love what I'm
doing right now and so I'm just going to
keep on doing it last question John
McCain took a lot of flack for his
choice of Sarah Palin a lot of people
thought it was a mistake Democrats
certainly made that argument not not so
much Republicans you picked John Edwards
and we've learned since that campaign
about a pretty sordid story involving
his family tragic story really when you
reflect on that story does that tell you
that you made the wrong decision in John
Edwards well everybody in the country
will make their own decision about about
that's choice at that point in time
what's happened since has obviously been
deeply troubling to everybody it's a
very tragic and in situation I know how
to just
but otherwise and I think it just it
speaks for itself I don't think any of
us have to sit here and start making
retro judgments that don't take anybody
anywhere I feel very very badly for for
for the family for all of them and and I
think the rest of it just so that speaks
for itself but you know a lot of
Democrats have said wow he could have
been our nominee and then that could
have come out do you ever thought that
all could have been vice president that
all happened subsequent to any of our
vetting process or any of our
relationship so what might have been in
2008 is different from what was in 2004
nevertheless obviously we all have to
make our reflections about what has
happened since and I have said I think
it's a tragedy and I think it speaks for
itself senator Kerry thanks for being
fresh eggs good routine thank you
you
